The premise of this video seems to be that there are fewer wars now because humanity is more peaceful, implying that humanity is changing for the better somehow. The main problem here is the old axiom that correlation does not mean causation. While the video is well-intentioned, I think its logic is flawed for a couple of reasons:
1. The narrator puts forward several explanations for the reduction in warfare in the last hundred years or so. However, as far as I recall, all the reasons provided are related to economic or political advantages over engaging in direct warfare with another country. No evidence is provided that we humans have actually changed our mindset to see warfare as wrong, barbaric, immoral, unethical, etc. Rather, it seems that we learned it is generally more advantageous to achieve the same nefarious objectives by other means instead of bombing another country.
2. Another key reason for the drastic reduction in large-scale wars between countries has most likely been the possession of large stockpiles of thermonuclear weapons by the key players (e.g. USA, USSR/Russia, China, etc.). As the computer WOPR in the 80s movie "War Games" nicely illustrated, there won't be many of us left to profit if a large-scale thermonuclear war broke out…
3. But I think one of the most misleading ideas in the video is the suggestion that, in the last decades, wars have almost always been within-country affairs rather than battles waged between countries. My view is that it becomes ever more challenging to hide atrocities, the destruction, or the loss of life within their own ranks when a country engages in a war somewhere else. History shows that wars are rarely 'quick' and tend to drag on, during which time more and more body bags are sent home. So I think what tends to happen nowadays is certain nations get others to fight for their interests instead. They provide money, intelligence, and/or weapons to different militiamen, insurgents, leaders, regimes, etc., who will stab, shoot, murder, bomb each other on their behalf. So rather than getting their sons sent home in bag bags, these nations encourage and support opposite warring sides, and if their 'team' wins, they can profit from the spoils of war afterwards. Between-country warfare has been going on for decades, but largely 'hidden' within the context of civil wars.
Maybe I am way too pessimistic, but after a few decades living on this planet, I think we have shown over and over again that under the right (or wrong!) circumstances, we continue to be as primitive, barbaric, and vicious as ever, ready to bomb the hell out of whoever challenges our interests or beliefs. In fact, over the last couple of years we have seen shocking levels of division and aggression within 'peaceful' and 'developed' nations because of political differences or just because someone asked us to wear a freaking mask. So, sadly, I have little doubt we remain as close to the Neanderthals as we were 500 hundred years ago… 😞

I think you guys must be intentionally missing that his largest point here was that State versus State conflicts had drastically gone down and might be on their way out eventually, not that they had vanished entirely, but most of the wars I'm able to think of since the end of World war II have been civil wars or at least we're started in that manner.

Vietnam, civil war Korea civil war, the breakup of Yugoslavia was a civil war, the stuff that's been going on the Congo has been civil war, Columbia's been in the state of civil war, the conflict between Pakistan and India is technically a civil war since they were once the same country.

Contrary to the idiom; War has changed (slightly).

It's not so much about who controls which areas of land or physical resources anymore (though that is still very much an aspect of hot warfare); it's now mostly about who controls the information. Information is the one resource that matters more than any other in todays version of warfare; you control information and you control public opinion, and if you control public opinion and you control any democratic society... It's the "achilleas heel" of democracy.
If the information is controlled by dishonest or biased (not necessarily "evil", just selfish) persons or groups (whether private, corporate or national) then the elected ruling class of people in a democratic society can quickly find themselves at odds with either their founding values or any newly emerging ideas. Then you end up with different classes of people who have different views of what reality is; one who believes in the reality according to the information they are provided with (these people end up being easily manipulated by the information controllers), one who believes in the reality they've seen and experienced (these people end up out of touch with developments in society around them), and one who believes in a reality according to what they've seen and experienced in conjunction with the information they are provided with (these people often end up either as leaders in one of the other groups or trying to bridge the divide between the other groups, and are usually at odds with the information controllers who caused the divide).

That's what makes things like state-controlled media or monopolies in the media or shared biases in the media so dangerous.

This video does not line up with the judgment of the organisation that maintains the Doomsday Clock. Since Trump came into power and started searching conflicts with North Korea, China and several other states, the organisation of the Doomsday Clock has set the clock to 90 seconds before twelve o' clock, twelve o' clock being the moment when humanity will run into a self created apocalypse, most likely WW3. According to the Doomsday Clock, we never were so close to self-annihilation, not even during the Korean War, the Cuban Crisis or the entire Cold War. And when Trump "left office"  things never became normal again. Covid 19, climate crisis, tensions with China and Russia at an all time high... so in 2014 this video may have sounded plausible, but not by the end of 2021.

One of the biggest things that changed is our technology. The strange truth is, the development of mechanized warfare began the decline of warfare itself. Nuclear weapons are a good example here. They forced two great empires to not wage direct war.

To put it simply, normal war only works if you can seize something of value afterward. Even conventional warfare these days costs more than you will ever get out of victory due to the damage inherent in it. You have to rebuild what you blow up for it to be any use to you.

Of course, if you are going to war for IDEOLOGICAL reasons, that is a different thing all together. We will see if this becomes the future shape of war. If so, then our wars will be far more brutal and bloody than even most historical wars. Extermination of an idea would be the goal, and you can only achieve that by wiping out everyone who believes it.

Another possibility is if some groups, such as the CCP, continue to show complete disregard for the planetary environment. I could see the necessity of warfare in this case in order to preserve what's left of the future environment. Nobody wants to talk about this, however.

And there is always the possibility of autocratic nations kicking off a large scale war by invading weaker neighbors that have alliances. I can see the possibility currently growing. These kinds of nations declare these types of wars because they are weakening at home, and need to rally their people against some foreign enemy in order to maintain domestic power.

In short, I think we are just before the deciding period. We are experiencing that deep intake of breath just before a profound statement is made. We will see what form that statement takes.

Yeah... I watch this video when it came out. I felt that something was off about it, but in my lack of knowlage I kept silent. As I simply didn't know what was wrong.

I think now I might know, just maybe. The problem I have with this video is that it assumes this all occurred naturally, and would progress as such.

This I feel was a mistake, and founded by a very modern ideas regarding the nature of war, and of peace. Many modern people, and it appers this video aswell. Hold the belief that war is something that only occurs when something has gone wrong. That war is the result of some horrible mistake, or wicked people trying to disrupt the natural order of things.

This from all my studies in history. I have found to be false. I believe the truth is as follows.
War is the natural consequence of nations acting as normal. War is just the continuation of politics by other means. As clausewitz said. Nations will naturally seek to expand their territory to show that their nation is healthy. To bring in additional resources, and to ensure a brighter future.

What we should be speaking up for is peace, democracy and an economic and political system where both corporate domination and domination by state authorities are intrinsically impossible. Only then we can have real confidence that this shit isn’t coming back.

These days, most violence is committed inside states, and it’s nonlethal by design. The goal is no longer to conquer new peasants, but to rule over them effectively and squeeze them as much as possible.

However, capitalism does have its own dynamics of war. It differs from Feudal dynamics that made war a common experience, but capitalism can lead to war as well in some circumstances. Paradoxically, Nations growing more and more interdependent does not make them more peaceful with each other. On the contrary: this interdependency is almost universally the main driver of conflict as this dependency is often quite asymmetric: one nation depends on imports, the other one on exports - and obviously, this is only good for the exporter in the long run; the other nation will exhibit all traits of an addict.

Usually, those conflicts are resolved in a tame manner. But they can escalate. World War I was an example of this: long before 1914, there had been a trade war spiraling and spiraling, eventually culminating in war.

The main factors preventing war today are the following: strong institutions and nukes. After World War II, there was a Long equilibrium of powers and a strong global framework of institutions. With the unipolar world after the Cold War, this institutional framework has been severely undermined, with the US and her allies continually ignoring what the UN have to say. Now it’s only nukes that make everyone afraid to cross red lines. This did have a positive effect, it did work for decades, but given how close we came to annihilation even during the Cold War, I really really don’t want this to be the only mechanism to protect us from war.

1) The biggest reason we might tend to assume things are terrible is the media. A couple hundred years ago, there could be a war where thousands died and you might never hear about it. 2) Nukes. Good, bad, or indifferent, a rough balance of power in nuclear weapons has definitely changed the calculus of major nations going to war. Using the stats they show here, one could argue that they've prevented far more deaths than they've caused.

Having learned about wars since they were written in stone, I honestly don't think we're going to go to war, instead the opposite. The thing is that humans need something to focus on, personally all I do is study humans and what they are doing today as opposed to the past. From what I can predict, the U.S. would need to become allies with Russia in order for peace to happen and that would start with nuclear disarmament on a massive scale. Nuclear deterrence is a huge part of why a war won't happen any time soon, but at the same time it'll result in a war that will kill almost all life and we'll have to restart evolution from the scraps that remain.

The other option is go to space and explore, focusing resources on space as opposed to vanity projects. We're already on the cusp of mining asteroids to try and supplement resources. The biggest conflict with all of this is that we have no reasonable place to explore in space with our limited technology.

About Congo & Belgium : it's no detail to precise that until 1908, the colony of Congo was not belgian but a weird capitalistic project, property of the sole Leopold II (which was indeed also king of Belgium), he gave up his "Independant state of Congo" to Belgium after media depictions of atrocities by his operators. The media campain was mostly coming from Great-Britain, because they had the best journalists of the time but also because GB had views on the huge Congo to made their "from Cairo to Cape" colonial project. The atrocities (handcutting and such) were facts but we don't know the real impact on population because we didnt and still dont know how many people inhabited that mostly unknown area during that period. After 1908, the ISC became the belgian congo and it became a common european colony, no better or worst than those of GB, France, Portugal,...
I have no sympathy for the "independant state of Congo" which was a greedy and cruel entity, but, well, it has never been belgian before 1908 and we don't know the casualties, we just know it was a bloody mess in which lots of europeans took part of (operators were belgians of course but also british, swedish, dutch,... to make it happen, Leopold II had to sell the ISC at the Berlin Congress as an "international liberal/capitalist entity", close to the statutes of the panama canal).

I would like to provide some sanity to the topic about ending war and perhaps the world needs a good dose of reality testing. The answer is so obvious that even a toddler can see it. Take all the money in the world used for warfare and self-destructive purposes and use it instead to provide the minimal basic needs for all of humanity such as food, water, shelter, education, health care, etc., and sit back and watch the causes for war vanish rapidly. Every time a country builds a modernized weapon or a fighter jet, just think how many people that could have fed. Ideally, government and laws wouldn't be necessary, but since this human race is so primitive, international government and law may be necessary to keep us from destroying ourselves.

AN INTERNATIONAL TRIBUNAL

“The true civilization will raise its banner when some noble kings of big ambitions, the bright suns of the world of humanitarian enthusiasm, shall, for the good and happiness of all the human race, step forth with firm resolution and keen mind and hold a conference on the question of universal peace; when keeping fast hold of the means of enforcing their views they shall establish a union of the states of the world, and conclude a definite treaty and strict alliance between them upon conditions not to be evaded. When the whole human race has been consulted through their representatives and invited to corroborate this treaty which verily will be accounted sacred by all the peoples of the earth, it will be the duty of the united powers of the world to see that this great treaty shall endure”. “ (Abdu'l-Baha, Divine Philosophy, p. 26)

A reflection of this parliament of man will be established in each community and called the “house of justice.” Its members will be chosen for their attribute of justice, and all matters pertaining to the community interests will be brought here for consultation.

UNIVERSAL PEACE

All men and nations shall make peace. There shall be universal peace amongst governments, universal peace amongst religions, universal peace amongst races, universal peace amongst the denizens of all regions. Today in the world of humanity the most important matter is the question of universal peace.

(Abdu'l-Baha, Divine Philosophy, p. 26)

That's total bullshit. You can't draw conclusions from the last 80 years. In the history of the world we know the periods called the Great Peace. Great peace occurs when a world superpower brings a geopolitical order to the world (all over the familiar world). The longest lasting Great Peace was Pax Romana. It lasted 265 years. This was achieved by democratizing and uniting most peoples, while other peoples were drawn into mutual trade, services and migration.
Another great peace was the Pax Britannica, and since the end of World War II the Pax Americana has continued. Unfortunately, the longer the sun shines, the more violent the storm comes, and this time it will be. We already have many countries that deny the current status que, countries that feel wronged by the current order and countries that the current order threatens, or is contrary to their interests. World War III is only a matter of time. We now have all the symptoms that existed before the Great War: regional conflicts in irrelevant countries, in which the powers engage to test their rivals, violations of established principles by various countries, territorial claims, invoking past wrongs and injustices, the economic domination and exploitation of weaker countries, growing claimant sentiments, the cult of sacrifice and a sense of injustice. The use of trade and economics as a tool of political pressure.

This video is a bit of a stretch. The lack of war casualties is not a result of countries becoming civilized and wanting to avoid war or conflict, with the remaining warring nations not yet being civilized enough.

Large powers realized that war is undesirable... for themselves. In order to avoid getting attacked, losing large sections of your population and having to rebuild your economy afterwards, they decided to stop getting directly involved in wars. (Also there's the whole "who'll press the nuke button first"-game) Now they just play the proxy war game and back forces behind a war, so they can have the industry advantages without the large losses associated with being directly involved in a full frontal war. They'll do some flexing for the other super powers, if they're feeling like it they'll do air strikes and precision ground attacks within the conflict itself. And they leave the war of attrition part to the local forces, whom they'll happily supply with plenty of weapons to do that fighting for them. Those superpowers wishing to retaliate will then also find a force in the conflict to back and see how much they can get away with without getting in the cross-hairs themselves.

Result: Endless conflict and armed power struggles everywhere in the region. But it's elsewhere in the world, with other people's lives, so who gives a shit, right?.

Two main issues that deter old style wars: Total war to the death concept and nuclear weapons. As mentioned in the video, a war between superpowers would be so costly and disastrous that it's not worth it anymore. Until the last two centuries, it'd mostly be like one or two field battle(s) and a country would give up after losing its single campaign army and its reinforcement. Now every single city block is fought for and everyone takes up arms. Residents of occupied areas also keep fighting an asymmetrical war. It's no longer worth it to waste a whole generation worth of economical power to get a couple of cities that will be in rabbles anyway. Moreover, birth rates dropped sharply which means that losing millions of young people ready for the workforce would be crippling to a country now.

Couple other related factors:
1) The cost of infrastructure is exponentially greater than it has been historically, and this infrastructure is fragile and easily destroyed by warfare. Infrastructure is thus extremely hard to protect, and nearly impossible to either capture intact or loot. As such, it is borderline impossible to profit directly from invading another country. You must risk far more than you stand to gain.
2) Nuclear weapons may have made large scale national warfare effectively meaningless, by magnifying point #1 above to an absurd degree. If an opposing nation is able to strike even a single large city belonging to an aggressor, that single strike will almost certainly cost that country more in population and material than they could ever hope to recoup via their aggression - again making war meaningless for economic gain.

You forgot the most important reason, nuclear weapons. All that free market and economy building won't deter someone from going to war if they firmly believe that they have the military might to takeover a target nation. The economy can always recover later, so they won't mind taking a hit on their economy, especially if they know their economy will do better after they have fresh new lands from recent conquest.

Right after the fall of the Axis at the end of World War 2, the Soviets were actually planning on invading the rest of Europe while prepping up Communist China to handle Asia for them. Only reason Stalin didn't go through with it was because America could already use nuclear weapons. Even if they could conquer all of Europe save for the British Isles, they were afraid that an American bombardment of atomic bombs could reverse those territorial gains, push them back to Soviet borders, and drop an atomic bomb on Moscow.

Even Churchill was planning on attacking the Soviets after defeating the Nazis, to catch them off guard while they were exhausted from crushing Berlin , because he knew that if the Soviets attacked a year or two later the Allies had no hope of winning against the Comintern in conventional warfare. Only reason he didn't go through with it was 1) The Allies at the moment were far too exhausted and spent to wage another prolonged and bloody war, and 2) He didn't know if the Soviets had already secretly developed their own arsenal of nuclear weapons, and were afraid of London meeting the same fate as Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Just look at the Cold War, a prime example of nuclear deterrence. If neither side had no nukes, do you honestly think the USSR, with the Warsaw Pact, wouldn't actually launch an invasion of Europe, overwhelm their defenses, and take full control of Europe? Of course they would, there was nothing to stop them. The Korean War? The Soviets would have marched with the North Koreans and Chinese to completely wipe out South Korea even if the Americans were there if there were no nukes between both sides.

Case in point, NUCLEAR WEAPONS SAVED DEMOCRACY.
Nuclear deterrence and mutually assured destruction are no joke, and its importance not reduced.

Kind of weird that you didn’t mention the way in which nuclear weapons locked all world powers out of war. At the end of your recent video on the use of nuclear weapons your tidbit about the banishment of nuclear weapons was extremely idealistic. The use of nuclear weapons against humans hasn’t happened since they were first developed. In fact no war between major powers has occurred since the development of nuclear weapons. There have been proxy wars, but they have never devolved into full on conflicts. Anyone who looks at a timeline can see that nuclear weapons have been the greatest catalyst for peace the word has ever known. Of course the points in this episode are valid and significant, but none of them stopped the Eastern Bloc and the Western Bloc from get at each other’s throats. It was the fear of retaliatory strike that prevented the Third World War. The doctrine of containment almost certainly would have fallen to public outcry had the societal conscious not been dissuaded due to the certainty of Mutually Assured Destruction. As the world becomes more democratic and the spread neoliberal philosophy accelerates, it may become more and more appealing to simply remove nuclear weapons from the world stage. The development of conflicts will always linger in the minds of opportunistic powers and without the fear of a retaliatory nuclear strike, a world without nuclear weapons could lead to the development of a far more unstable planet.

Of course the ICC doesn’t really administer justice as intended. In fact it’s only ever held African leaders to account. Since the Nüremberg trials 39 of 39 convictions at the ICC were of African leaders. They only ever “consider” trying others. Their justification for not trying Tony Blair, Dick Cheney, and others for lying to the U.N. in order to mislead the Security Council into sanctioning the invasion of Iraq was that they’re only concerned with the crimes committed during an invasion not with the invasion itself. Of course, that discounts the fact that there were war crimes beyond the invasion, such as helicopters attacking aid workers and journalists, drone strikes hitting civilians, and torture, on top of the real issue which is what is a bigger crime during war than starting the war under false pretenses in the first place. When confronted with these arguments the ICC states the distinction is that the African Union wants ICC intervention, where the EU and North America do not. But of course one can find a morally comparable analogy to the policing of demographically isolated neighborhoods. If the police only ever arrest people in the black neighborhood and never arrest people in a white neighborhood, it doesn’t really matter whether some people in the black neighborhood want the police to do their job and no people in the white neighborhood want the police to do their job. The wishes of the people in the neighborhood are irrelevant to what the police should do.

I think the most of the reasons mentioned in the video are not so relevant. on my opinion there are three main factors and reasons: globalisation, technology, intellectual & social developments.

globalisation: as the world is getting more and more interconnected, the potential wars are increasingly becoming more like negative-sum games than zero-sum games as before. in other words: it's just not worthy to participate in war in a globalised world.

technology: as the world is getting more and more advanced in terms of technology so also in terms of weapons, the potential wars are increasingly becoming more and more dangerous, i.e. massive. this is why after the World War II, which was ended by two atomic bombs (the first and last time when atomic weapon was used in practice), there has been no more larger-scale military conflict among states. and this is also the reason why the Cold War was "cold". this game theoretic situation is called as the principle of "mutual destruction", which is also related to the concept of negative-sum games, where no participant can be a real winner. in other words: it's just not worthy to participate in war in a technologically advanced world.

intellectual & social developments: I know that most of the times it's not visible and clear, but humans can learn, and humanity does learn from the past. this is the engine of development and social evolution. so this also means that things which are bad in nature are getting more and more associated with their true attributes, image and nature by us. this means that every bad thing is becoming more and more visible to us as "bad thing". this is just as true for wars as for dictatorships. the only exception is when the "bad thing" tries to come back in a new form. this has already happened to the two mentioned examples. wars still exist, but in a more abstract and sophisticated way (e.g. information or economic wars), and autocratic systems have also returned, but in a more abstract and sophisticated form as well (e.g. postmodern / hybrid autocracy, which was already predicted by Orwell in his book of "1984"). this partly cyclic (in terms of return of these constructs), partly acyclic (in terms of transformation of these constructs) dynamical process reveals the dialectic nature of social evolution. but even if "wars" have returned in new forms and more abstract ways, the earlier raw and brutal physical variant of mass conflicts is not something which is preferred by masses anymore. and this is analogous to the fact that no political force or party defines itself as dictatorship or autocracy, instead they always hide behind the disguise of democracy. why? because today EVERYBODY knows that dictatorship and autocracy are bad. so learning from the past accumulates knowledge, which with time creates "common knowledge" in the society. and this "state of social mind" eliminates the given "bad thing" forever (as long as the society preserves its past and earlier falls and breakdowns). in other words: people just don't want to participate in something that is considered to be bad by almost everyone.

So let's please do be clear about this much, because it makes the rest of your video highly, highly, highly suspect: The reason there are fewer casualties now is most assuredly NOT because war between states is going out of fashion; it's because it's being fought much more cleverly and generally by proxy. For one thing, many of the civil and "local" conflicts you mention (and what, exactly, is a "local" conflict if not a civil one, never mind I guess) are actually the result of intentional destabilization of one or both sides by outside powers. And for another, the reason that there are fewer casualties is because the technology of warfare has evolved to focus less on un-telegenic civilian casualties, and more on inflicting lasting and much more sanitary damage to the other side's capacities. There were fewer deaths per 1,000,000 in World War Two than in the US Civil War, but that doesn't mean it was less of a war, friends.

We no longer live in an era of physical warfare on a large scale in terms of war. We currently live in an era that is alarmingly filled with psychological warfare which is much more harmful to nation states. With people being more connected then ever, it has become much easier to sway their sentiments and behavior in favor of non-state actors to create chaos and uncertainty to exploit each individual's resources. This chaos won't become apparent, it works beneath the surface in the minds of people to subtly alter their values and beliefs. By the time 75 years would have passed, the world will not look anything like it looks today. When a frog is thrown to a boiling water, it will reflexively escape whereas a frog that has been kept in water at ambient temperature with the temperature gradually raised to boiling it wouldn't realise this change and just perish. The main reason we haven’t seen a major conflict between nations in any form, other than proxy wars, is because of the idea of collective defense, or many nations ganging up on an aggressor to defend a victim state. This concept has become adopted throughout the world as we have seen with the UN member states, with the main contributor to global stability being the United States.

However, when there are no major threats outside, people tend to find enemies inside. The wars of the future will be civil wars fought over cultural, political, religious, economic, or racial differences. Resource wars will still occur in impoverished regions, but those in the first world will be due to age old tensions long believed put aside.

My suspect, however, that this will not be the case should the US go down this route. If it does, Russia and China will mobilize to take advantage of the sudden international power vacuum left by a world without America to help. Many Asian countries will find China banging on their door, while nations formerly members of the USSR will find their sovereignty under threat as well. Kim Jong Un will invade South Korea after many of America’s troops return to restore order, if it is in fact that dire.

Also, since conflict between countries became a major rarity, many first world countries have made serious cuts to their national defense budgets. If the US disappeared, you would find dozens of countries rapidly increase their military size to avoid being rolled over by aggressive neighbors.

For peace to be maintained, the US must be maintained, unless we want more warfare and death in places that haven’t seen war since the last world war.

I object to the implication that colonialism caused war in various nations.
This misses out the rather salient point that, before europeans arrived on boats, these areas were already hotbeds of inter-clan wars and genocides.

Everywhere humans have lived was an area of constant war at some point.
You could argue that colonial exploitation stalled or reversed the development of these areas, which might explain why they're taking longer to catch up with prosperity.

But its also equally possible that these areas were simply more primitive to begin with.
While the aztecs were building pyramids and sacrificing virgins, england was building universities and discovering all manner of sciences. Now central america is an area rife with drugs and gang violence. But without spanish settlers wouldn't it just be an area of jungle tribes genociding each other? It certainly wasn't a peaceful utopia when spain arrived

Less advanced areas of the world got conquered by more advanced nations, but the longterm development of these conquered regions may have been accelerated by this

The idea that democracies don't fight each other is more of a cold-war era coincidence then any sort of greater trend (in that most democracies at the time existed in Western Europe, which was under de facto American domination at that time). As democracy spreads, it doesn't just evaporate existing casus bellis. The 2006 Israeli invasion of Lebanon is a good example. The fact that Lebanon is (mostly) a democracy doesn't change the last 70 years of regional politics.

Furthermore, if the recent atrocities committed by Myanmar in the Rakhine are any indication, democracies are every bit as capable of mindless blood-lust, and genocide, as their dictatorial counterparts. Now, you can say that neither Israel, Lebanon, or Myanmar are what we would call "pure democracies", but I believe the point still stands. A democratically elected US govt is just as willing to invade Iraq as a non-democratic Russia is to invade Georgia or Ukraine.

I mean, wars are getting more and more potent. The Hundred Years War caused 2.7 million deaths in 112 years. Meanwhile, the Syrian Civil War has caused 560,000+ deaths in the last 5 years. If the Hundred Years War had the same death rate, it would've led to 12.5 million deaths. Now, for another comparison: The Thirty Years War caused 5.9 million deaths in 30 years. The Bangladeshi War of Independence caused 3 million deaths in 1 year. Think about that. There's less wars, but they're more and more potent. Imagine the deaths from World War 3, which are estimated to be 100 million to 1 billion depending on how many nuclear weapons are used (excluding the possibility of nuclear winter, which is thought to lead to 4-5 billion more deaths) and so on. It would most likely last between 6 months and 5 years, which will make it several times more potent than WWII. However, this is merely speculation, but a show of what we can do given the will.

The real reason we have no massive scale wars anymore is because one superpower came out triumphant in the coldwar and rules as hedgemon with an alliance made up of the ten next most powerful countries, all of which have American bases in them. No, we didn't outgrow war, we are not more enlightened (how can anyone possibly be so arrogant?), we're living in the shadow of a global empire that rules through both hard and soft power whose hedgemonic rule is slowly, shakily, coming to an end. We won't have another globe spanning hedgemon like the United States, or the British Empire ever again and thank God for it. It will mean more wars in the future, but I would honestly rather that than soulless rule as vassal to someone else's empire, no matter how 'good' it is.

Another point: Definition games are fun, but civil wars and 'regional conflicts' are still wars. This is the no-true-scotsman fallacy applied to concepts rather than people, a bit like saying 'democracies don't declare wars on eachother' and then stating that every cited example of democracies or democratically elected governments that declared war on eachother 'weren't real democracies' either. Its insulting and condescending. Wars happen even today and will happen again in the future and always will, its a reality of Human Nature and the only thing that will stop it is a globe spanning empire that enforces peace through force. A bit like what the Globalist movement is attempting to create out of naive idealism that will inevitably end in disaster because it ignores human tribalism, both its good and bad aspects and will provoke rebellion and conflict at the base level never mind wider scale rebellions with ideological motivations.

Because Humans. Don't. Change. Not ever. And no amount of ideological quackery of philosophical handwaving is going to result in human nature itself being changed. It this upsets you, then I am sorry, you should really toughen up your mindset and see the beauty and goodness are worth fighting, dying, and yes, killing for. Evil exists, it exists in all of us to some extent, even the best of us and war is a consequence of the reality of evil. Its why you can get wars like WW1 where no side was truly the 'bad guy' but all sides committed horrific atrocities, and why you get wars like WWII where one side is almost comedically evil, but the 'good guys' still get the show started on mass firebombing and terrorbombing civilian targets and unleashing ungodly weapons like nukes. War doesn't make us evil, we make war because we're evil, and the sooner everyone starts to accept that, the sooner we can get back to reality based politics and actually start making real progress again rather than just coasting on the momentum of the last two centuries.

Note: Also, bold of you to assume Colonialism has ended. I mean thats basically what China is doing to Africa right now.

My defense for the claim generally is this:

Such technologies are generally spread a cross world powers in short order as we saw with Nukes themselves. If the US invents the anti nuke technology it would enjoy only a short global complete domination before another power gets ahold of the technology and spreads to allies.

Now if everyone has rendered Nukes as outdated as traditional cannonball artillery what is stopping a country like India from more staunchly enforcing its armed claims against Pakistan, or China for that matter.

Russia took Eastern Europe many times throughout history most recently during the formative years of the Soviet Union right before Nukes were invented. You can expect they’ll resume their historical trend once Nukes are off the table once again.

That is nothing to say of the Middle East and the potential for the resolution of a war hundreds of years in the making. Or China’s ambitions to create a modern communist empire in East Asia?

Without the threat of Nuclear Arsenal’s America can only keep so much of the world in order. Something somewhere is bound to go unchecked and snowball into a massive conflict

The reason the world is relatively stable is that most of the world is prosperous enough that people will not support a war. That will change within the next 20 years. Points of conflict:
- Africa: Nations are not along ethnic lines, and really, the borders of that entire continent should be redrawn now that it's all independent. But those currently in power would never support that. So you end up with nations that aren't really nations, just slabs of land that were originally divided by the colonial powers, and which the african people (as in the people on that entire continent) feel no loyalty to.
- Europe: A persistent and increasing refugee flow coupled with repeated "incidents" caused by said migrants is causing strong nationalist and xenophobic sentiments in many nations. In some parts of the EU these sentiments have gained a majority (Poland is an example) and they are basically telling the EU that enough's enough. But the africans keep on coming in droves - uneducated, unskilled workers that have basically no chance in the western knowledge-based economy, and are thus condemned to lower class existances. This disparity will cause friction, and has the potential to trigger civil wars within the EU.
- US: As the US continues to isolate itself, it may face an economic slump. And whenever things go bad with the economy in the US, a proxy war is soon to follow. China and the EU are seeking closer ties. This may break the old alliances between the US and western Europe.
- Within the coming decade I see roughly 5 global powers emerge: The US, the EU, Russia and it's close allies, China and it's close allies, and the South American nations. Africa will need a few more generations to sort itself out. Australia is an odd one out, not really a major power but not tied to any specific one either. But it's own economic base is too small to be considered a power unto itself. These powers are already shoving and prodding at eachother.

Trigger points?
- Terrorist nuke. It's bound to happen at some point, given the amount of nuclear material. Wether a true thermonuclear device or just a dirty bomb, the detonation of a nuclear weapon in peace time sets a precedent that'll require an armed response against anyone even remotely responsible. It'd dwarf 9/11 by several orders of magnitude, especially if it strikes a densely populated area (New York, Moscow, Bejing, Singapore, Berlin... just to name a few targets).
- Peak oil OR post oil. Peak oil is when the oil reserves are no longer able to meet demand. Post oil is when another renewable energy source (such as nuclear fusion) essentially makes oil obsolete as a fuel, causing it's price to plummet. Both scenarios mean the entire mideast loses it's source of income. And we've seen what happens when nations under islamic rule have a population that have no hope of a decent existance. Not sure when peak oil will happen, but the first fusion plants that are expected to be economically viable are already being constructed.
- Overstrained social safety net causes economic crash. Especially dangerous for Europe, with both a migrant flow putting a drain on it's social support, and the babyboom generation retiring, meaning more elderly folk to care for then there are adults to do that care. There is, as far as I can tell, no plan for when this will inevitably come crashing down. It'll be bad for the old folks. I expect crimewaves the likes even the US would do a doubletake at...
- Next US elections. I mean, Trump will need to make some chance for himself to get reelected, right?

And no, I don't see North Korea as a potential sore spot. If that nation launches a nuke in any direction it'd be bombed so far back to the stoneage by both the Chinese and the US that whichever Kim's at the helm at that point would literally have to crap bricks. I also don't really see Israel and Iran as a potential sore spot, for largely the same reasons. Mutually Assured Destruction is a lovely concept. No, war triggers when a nation has little to nothing left to lose, and potentially a lot to gain.

The relative peace we enjoy today is a direct result of global communication and education. It is possible to negotiate peace, because its easy to contact the enemy and discuss terms for ceasefire - not to mention the fact, that you can't hide the horrors of war anymore, genocide, war crimes, weapons of mass destruction, and labor camps are exposed by the media, by satelite photos, or by the people on the inside, you can no longer blame the atrocities of war on the fog of war. The World is watching.

The most peaceful regions in the World are also the best educated - smart people realize that war is counter-productive, and smart people are much better at using their words to fight their battles. When you are at a loss for words, you resort to violence, that is basic human nature, when you can't argue against your opponent, you get angry and want to punch them in the face. Education also means an understanding of diplomacy, and the concept of compromise, that both parties getting some of what they want, rather than one party getting all and the other getting nothing - at the cost of millions of lives - is the better option.

Most importantly, Mutually Assured Destruction (appropriate acronym) ensures that it is impossible to invade or attack most nations, because the cost of war would always outweigh the potential benefits - Not just because of the stockpile of weapons of mass destruction, but the collaboration of the nations of NATO, which means that declaring war on a country will mean a war with the most of the world as a whole. And as long as USA remains part of NATO, the entire western world is too massive a military beast for any rational person to challenge. If USA and EU splits, this peaceful era may come to and end - bloated as America's military budget is, alone they wouldn't be half as intimidating to China, Russia, or Iran.

Communication and Education are the two primary pillars of peace, and should be fostered all over the world, if we want to completely eliminate the concept of war.

War is being fought RIGHT NOW. Why did people fight wars to begin with? It has to do with gaining control and exercising policy as well as gaining resources (which is no longer best gained by war but by trade). Like the video said, it is no longer feasible for traditional war, the public effect is too large (everyone is neighbor on the global scale and you don't want to be the shitty neighbor, but naturally the bigger the neighbor you are the shittier you can get away with being) and you would rather reap the benefits of trade to begin with. Now how is war still being fought? We live in the Information Age. If you are at all familiar with the events surrounding the US election and Russia's involvement then you are familiar with modern warfare. This is how war is fought now. This is how large superpowers wrest for control and work to exercise their agendas and policies upon eachother. This is how Russia aimed to destabilize the USA in order to shift the balance of power. This is how every major superpower, China, Russia, and USA( which is more or less aligned with the rest of the Western World), all fight to sway the scales. Instead of soldiers and guns you have social scientists, analysts, writers, and programmers with computers. Instead of fighting over positions they fight over the hearts and minds of the common man, to sway our attitudes and opinions. Ideas are powerful, the thought contagion (an idea that spreads like a virus) is the most powerful weapon in human history. Maybe the day will come when astroturfing, this covert trolling is seen for the act of terror that it is, brainwashing humanity and turning us against eachother, our brothers and sisters arbitrarily born under different cultures, races, and flags. Until then all we can do is remember this fact, and shelter this small yet brightly burning flame from the storm that is to come.

War. War never changes.
The Romans waged war to gather slaves and wealth. Spain built an empire from its lust for gold and territory. Hitler shaped a battered Germany into an economic superpower.

But war never changes.

In the 21st century, war was still waged over the resources that could be acquired. Only this time, the spoils of war were also its weapons: Petroleum and Uranium. For these resources, China would invade Alaska, the US would annex Canada, and the European Commonwealth would dissolve into quarreling, bickering nation-states, bent on controlling the last remaining resources on Earth.

In 2077, the storm of world war had come again. In two brief hours, most of the planet was reduced to cinders. And from the ashes of nuclear devastation, a new civilization would struggle to arise.

A few were able to reach the relative safety of the large underground vaults. Your family was part of that group that entered Vault Thirteen. Imprisoned safely behind the large Vault door, under a mountain of stone, a generation has lived without knowledge of the outside world.

It is always assumed that leopold 2 was extremely horrible and while that is probably correct, it does seem like a lot of videos I encounter on youtube that touch upon this subject like this one are a bit lacking in nuance, which is understandable as leopold 2 isn't the main point of the video.

But looking back at history and saying: 'It was his colony and this is how many people were mutilated and killed, ergo leopold 2 killed so many people' is wrong. For example, do you know how many times leopold 2 visited Congo? - The answer is zero.

His focus was on making money and gaining stature by having a colony, but that doesn't necessarily mean he intended for so many cruelties to happen there. A great book that also touches on this subject is 'Congo. een geschiedenis' ('Congo. A history') by the belgian author David Van Reybrouck.

War has changed.

It's no longer about nations, ideologies, or ethnicity. It's an endless series of proxy battles, fought by mercenaries and machines.

War--and it's consumption of life--has become a well-oiled machine.

We are not on the road to lasting peace. While democracy and capitalism have somewhat stabilized the global nation state system, that nation state system ultimately depends upon the abundance of natural resources to null the need for military conflict. Once those resources start to become increasingly more scarce... wars will start to occur as the disparity between "haves" and "have nots" becomes wider. The tricky thing about peace is (which I thought the paradox mentioned in the title was going to be) is that the simplest way to achieve peace is to kill everyone who disagrees with you. Is that sort of peace really to be desired? And is there an other sort of peace?
Sure there is - peace made by discussion and sharing points of view. The problem is that many people are not open to that. Or is in fact anyone fully open to other points of view? The idea of peace for example is a point of view that peaceful people (like me I guess) generally don't want to change. So what do we do? Establish peace by force?
I'm all for peace, I wish we could achieve it, but people differ from each-other and... is it a good thing? I think that at least to some extent it is. And disagreements are a logical side-effect of this diversity.
What is the conclusion? I don't know.
But it's something to think about.

It is not, sadly. Another great war will come because of the automation paradox: Each automated profession yields a number of jobs that require good education and therefore high pay, for example in research, construction, and maintenance of these machines; which one might assume is desirable for first-world countries. However, the high wages of these professions slow the process down, as employers figure that it is at this point cheaper to pay an entire factory of low-skilled workers in third-world countries than machines in the first world.

As machines become cheaper with technological advances, the workforce of the third world has to earn even lower wages to remain employable, which will at one point in time go below what is biologically necessary to survive. The employer therefore has to switch to machinery in order to keep producing, which will leave more and more third-world workers unoccupied, with no insurance, little health care, not even a prospect of education, and entirely drained of the fruits of their labour. When this happens to large groups of people down there, they are going to rebel.

As for the first world, there is going to come a depression; because with the third world the companies will also lose a big consumption market. We will paradoxically have too many goods distributed among too few people, all the while we will receive even more economy refugees from Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Middle East. This will lead to tensions between the rich westerners and the poor immigrants; a taste of what will come already happens in Germany and France. First-world countries will face even more terrorist attacks as people in the developing world turn to religion, specifically Islam, as their last resort.

The narrative of this video is both technically true and hugely misleading: it correctly notes that there has been a large decline in battlefield deaths, and completely ignores the fact that most of the people killed by modern warfare are civilians. We are not killing fewer and fewer people - we are killing more, but fewer of them are soldiers. So we are wonderful democratic visionaries because we mainly kill the innocent by massive aerial bombardment, rather than risk military casualties by actually engaging the enemy and fighting like men. If we throw the million or so mainly civilian deaths from just one of our recent wars (Iraq) into the equation, rather than counting only the deaths of soldiers and insurgents, our statistics don't look quite so rosy. Not to even mention this is a gross distortion of reality.

Vietnam was supposed to be an advisory role only but Johnson got sucked in.

Thousands have been killed around the world but it took a huge attack on 9/11 to make the US actually get serious and take action and even then they held back so much that the wars have dragged on for decades. I have always had trouble reconciling contemporary human history. People can be, and are, so nasty towards one another for reasons that I often consider arbitrary or misguided. Conflicts around the globe are from black and white and their causes can likely be traced centuries into the past. But where does the fighting and malice end?

As a 21 year old Haitian-American who lives in America, I suppose my perspective on many of these global conflicts are extremely limited. After all, I don't live through those conflicts. Nonetheless, I live my life in the name of spreading KPR (Kindness, Positivity, and Respect). The world has enough negativity as it is. If I don't spread positive vibes and diplomacy, who will?

It's tough to critically think about these things while focusing on my own life at the same time. I wish I that wouldn't get so preoccupied with issues that I cannot fix. 5 - mutually assured destruction (nuclear annihilation)

A beautiful presentation with a wonderful viewpoint and some great (though selective) evidence presented; unfortunately, despite how compelling this presentation is, it does not address some of the simpler elements in life that have persisted for so long they can safely be assumed to be immutable facts of life.

There will always be war.

The idea that democracy is responsible for a growth in peace is a nice one but it's difficult to prove as when we observe change it's common practice to associate it with something, a catalyst, that has brought about that change but when there are an immense number of factors and not all of them are readily observable it becomes all too easy to incorrectly label or attribute/blame something for being a catalyst when in fact it is not.

It might be democracy that reduces armed conflict or it could be that the spread of democracy over x timeline coincides with an increase in arms technology that has intimidated nations into taking a peaceful stance until they feel confident they have a sufficient level of technological advancement and production which is required for open hostilities against a foreign power.

Take World War one and two for example, one 'side' had a clear technological advantage over the other which I have zero doubt was a large contributor toward their confidence and enabled them to get the ball rolling. Human nature is all but immutable and there will always be nations/dictators and other such looking to expand their holdings/fighting for resources as if it's not need that motivates conflict it's greed.

Limited resources, overpopulation, unhappy masses, envy of quality of life or desperation and of course the arms race and a perceived advantage over someone else, take your pick... There's plenty of motivators for conflict and not all warfare is physical in this day and age; we have nation spying on nation but it's not just the undercover agent anymore it's digital surveillance, tapping into communications, satellites and all the other associated technology and methodology employed by such parties.

Deterrence is a large part of it, enter the nuclear weapon and M.A.D (mutually assured destruction) and the picture becomes clearer.

The notion that any nation or combatant cares about rules is laughable, none of the major governments are going to pass up a major opportunity due to legal/mutually agreed upon restrictions or the like, such things are just another arena for warfare of another kind and the reason such things don't work is because there's no trust; it's understandable, when you're looking at nations dealing with one another, particularly when the topic is warfare there's simply no room for trust in that theater...

Russia isn't going to take any risks with the US based on trusting that the US will also change their ways etc.

We will NEVER see any nation dismantle and destroy their entire nuclear arsenal due to some UN agreement, the only way any of them are going to get rid of their nukes is if they're clearing them out to make room for the new and nastier thing that's going to be replace them, their new intimidation baton if you will.

Of course that won't stop them from lying about it and the unending political and militaristic games go on unabated.

Open warfare is only one facet of conflict these days, just part of a larger scheme. Before nation A attacks nation B they spend years attempting to break down ties between B and its allies, they try to undermine their global political image and attack their economy and infrastructure all the while spying on them and testing them; they want to make sure they have every conceivable/obtainable advantage over them before showing their hand; in the meantime they all smile and shake hands for the camera so everyone looks like the good guy.

Nations aside there's extremist groups and all sorts of other shit out there. At the end of the day the only true law in life is natures law and everything else is just a leash for those who are willing to weather its grip. As long as you have something that someone else wants you're going to have to oppose every action others take to alleviate you of your possessions.

Whether they're fighting for resources or over a dispute in ideology/religion or whatever the case may be people will always fall back onto violence to get their way, the only difference between a brute and a pacifist is for a pacifist violence is a last resort.

I should add as a final note that I am not stating that everything in this presentation was wrong and my views are correct; I am stating, whilst the factors presented in the presentation are more than likely contributors to why we have less conflict, they are likely not the largest contributors to that peace... I suspect the elements I have written about in this post are larger contributors to this current decline in open, physical conflict.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

T.L.D.R:

The reason things appear more peaceful right now is the major players are waiting for the right time or opportunity to play their next moves; nations don't trust their allies and the weapons of war are more destructive then ever before so the risks are higher and the powers that be want to make sure they have a superior standing before engaging in conflict.

Before we declare humanity changed, I think a little longer look is in order. First, is there less war? By the standards cited in the video, it would seem so. The evidence given is very persuasive. Could it also be, however, that things which used to require an armored division now only require a predator drone or two? Overall amount of carnage is lower, but not exactly evidence that the human race is evolving. Second, violence among nations has decreased, but violence on a smaller scale-- person to person or violence by groups of terrorists, for example-- is alive and well. Having said that, my understanding is that this form of violence is decreasing, as well, worldwide. Finally, perhaps we should also consider if the part of our humanity that leads to wars is just finding a new outlet in the culture of greed and consumerism. Less carnage and destruction, thank God, but undercuts the statement that humans are growing/improving. It would be like saying that I've cleaned up my act because I'm now addicted to crack instead of alcohol. You make a very good case when it comes to armed international conflict. That one statement is a logical leap too far, I think.

Very true! and good. It's about time we started to get our shit together - after all, it's been ~10,000 years since the dawn of civilization. However, what scares me is the growing concern over resources, particularly food and oil. People like their war machines regardless of how much they use them, and while companies like Tesla have been making increasingly viable electric vehicles, nobody is trying to make electric tanks or planes that use something other than jet fuel. Oil is a temporary resource, so at some point somebody will likely try to seize it as the price goes up and military demand stays the same. Worse yet, there is still a huge quantity of desperately poor in the world, and everybody needs to eat. In first world countries, sustainable and efficient farming methods are being implemented. In Africa and much of Asia, methods are neither although the world population steadily increases. There are easy ways to distribute food to people in need, but nothing scares people more than the idea of even temporarily running out of food. Fear leads to war all the time, so we (probably) will see heavy armed conflict withing the next 75 years, during which the human populating will start getting too big for the food we produce.

This video neglects two other major factors. The first, which the video vaguely tiptoed around, is Pax Americana. Historically, the best route to peace was for there to be only 1 superpower whereas balanced power typically causes warfare. WWI, for example, happened largely due to Europe having several nations with some levels of military parity. With the collapse of the Soviet Empire, America now possesses the strongest military in the world. Furthermore, America shares some level of military allegiance with most other wealthy, industrialized nations bolstering it's already impressive military might. Any nation that picks a fight with America, NATO allies of America, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea or a whole host of other countries we're aligned with would automatically be fighting the most powerful military in the world plus several of its allies.

The second reason war had declined is nuclear weapons. Most likely, were nuclear weapons never invented, the Cold War would've been quite hot. The USA wanted to destroy the USSR and the USSR wanted to destroy the USA but neither side was willing to commit suicide in the process. The five permanent members of the UN Security Council all have extensive nuclear capabilities and all are aware that any hot war between any two of them would basically render the northern hemisphere of the planet nearly lifeless.

I know I'm late for the party, but I wanted to add the very smalle suggestion, that you should make a comparison between the population impact of wars through time.

For example: The Second Punic War between Carthage and Rome in the third century BC (or the 908th HE) saw the death of 60.000 roman soldiers. Considering the fact that Rome's population was ~300.000 people at this point, the population impact was a horrifying 20%.

Another example would be the second world war, in which 60 million or 3% of the world population perished. If we optimistically assume that world population will cap at 12 billion, a 3% cataclysm would kill 660 million people, or about two times the current US population.

I just think this comparison would've been interesting when looking at these once-or-twice-per-century mega wars, and during my short research for this comment I couldn't find any of that sort.

One factor you left out was the impact of nuclear weapons. The U.S. and the Soviet Union almost certainly would have initiated world war 3 if the only options were conventional weapons. So paradoxically the most destructive weapon ever conceived prevented what would have potentially been the bloodiest war in history.

The threat of mutually assured destruction allowed cooler heads to prevail. Of course if things were rewound and played over again, they could have gone much differently. But as it turned out, in our world at least, nuclear weapons have ironically been a force for peace.

Now the roles are a bit different, and we are starting to realize that conflict isn't worth the cost.

The reason wars between states have become less common, is because states themselves became less relevant in a globalized world. But this is just a temporary phenomenon. By the decline of the role of the nation-state, people will increasingly start feeling under-represented over time, (imposition of alien values, crumbling economy, crumbling social cohesion) and under-representation will cause them to rebel against what's left of their state (which is why civil wars already started surging). But they will have to find an alternative means of social organisation, which will better represent their needs/interests, and this will give rise to new smaller states. (like those in the middle ages) This will be the active phase of de-globalization. And then these smaller states will again merge into larger states. The cycle will repeat. It's just nature. As for nukes, the nuclear dilemma implies that for as long as nukes continue to exist, sooner or later they will be used, either accidentally or intentionally. It's a mathematical conclusion. And MAD is not eternal. An alternative to de-globalization is the idea of a global government. But even if we succeed in creating something as monstrous as a global government, it should be obvious to anyone that it won't be able to last, as the amount of red tape produced by the requirement to represent the interests of 7+ billion people by a single organisation, will be too heavy to carry through. And de-globalization will inevitably follow suit.

To counter signal the Belgian point a bit.  Almost all of the violence committed in the Congo, was done by other Congolese.  The Belgians rarely stepped foot in the colony past the coast to pick up the rubber and other cash crops.  The Congolese murdered and enslaved each other in order for their tribe to control the plantations to sell the products to the Belgians.  When we say Belgian Congo, we mostly mean that King Leopold made a deal with the rest of the European powers to give him exclusive trading rights with the Congo, he did not directly interfere.  Don't get me wrong, the way his trading company operated encouraged the destruction, but it wasn't them doing it.  Also, you picked the absolute worst scenario for colonialization.  If you look at India or Rhodesia, quality of life greatly improved under colonial rule from a materialist perspective (as it did in almost all British and French colonies).

You are neglecting the biggest factor in the lack of international conflict: nuclear weapons. They are they only reason there was not a 3rd world war between the USSR and USA during the cold war. Mutually Assured Destruction (MAD) has done more to deter conflict than any ideal or organization. Simply put, there is no way to win a war that guarantees the destruction of both sides and the rest of the world in every iteration. That is what has prevented major powers from declaring war on each other.

MAD is the biggest reason that a war has not broken out between China, Russia, and/or the United States. International law is a joke for any major power because all the major powers hold a permanent position in the UN security council. This means that the US, UK, France, China, and Russian can do whatever they want without fear of UN sanctions. All P5 members have nuclear arsenals which makes it necessary to negotiate with and accommodate them since force is off the table.

The ICC relies on P5 members capturing and turning over war criminals for trial. Try to name a situation in which one of the P5 members would commit a war crime and any of the other 4 would invade to arrest the offending party. All the P5 members have nukes so to invade them to arrest someone would risk total global annihilation. This is why the nuclear powers get away with numerous violations of international law. The US uses chemical weapons (white phosphorous) and tortures people at gitmo and various black sites. China executes/tortures dissidents and violates the sovereignty of many Pacific nations; it also violates numerous agreements about international trade. Russia kills dissidents and oppresses minorities while invading its neighbors with flimsy justification. These 3 nations, along with England and France can do what they want because using force against them would mean mutually assured destruction.

Modern Economics is not a concrete reason to deter aggression. An economy is just a means to an end. That end is the ability to create a better military and keep the people happy. The real goal of a nation is to control as much of the world as possible. Profitable trade will not deter war if one nation thinks war can lead them to have compete control over a previously shared economic asset or even just some economic advantage. Look to the Empires of WWI fighting over colonies and control of Europe, Look to the Empires of WWII fighting over control of the World, Look to the Cold War where open conflict only took a back seat to proxy wars and negotiation because open warfare would mean the world ending inside of 20 minutes.

The bottom line is we are not more civilized or peaceful. Our lack of wars is a symptom of the stick that is nuclear weapons. We are simply coerced to avoid conflict because a modern world war would wipe out the entire planet. We still live in the Wild West and we are all still bandits, but we don't shoot because we are stuck in a Mexican stand off.

It  is cheaper finance a civil war that invading a country, with the result that resources are sold to foreign powers rather than directly stolen. They always say the world is too economically integrated to go to war, and yet-- World War 1, World War 2, both happened while people said history was over and done with and then was the time of everlasting peace.

Just one problem, though: the 5 stage Civilization cycle. Every civilization that reaches stability (Stage 3) then enters a period of stagnation (Stage 4), followed by their fall (Stage 5). The society becomes soft and pleasure-centered (Stage 4) and thus lacks the power to defend itself against the next civilization on the rise (Stage 5). True, democracies don't fight each other very often, but not everyone can/will become a democracy, so while the democracies get soft, there will still be that one society who becomes the wolf that preys on the sheep.

In other words, we can't rule out the possibility of the one crazy society / organization with a nuke. Even if everyone did become a democracy, the stagnation of Stage 4 could still produce that one group with a technology capable of mass destruction. Civilization's threat was a large number of barbarians. Now it's a small number of nuclear terrorists.

We don't go to war these days not because we've grown more peaceful but because we've grown more lazy. Democracy isn't peaceful because democracy is a virtuous system; it's peaceful only because war is no longer in vogue and politicians want to be re-elected. Democratically elected politicians  were largely responsible for WWI, WWII, the Korean War and the Vietnam War, to name but a few recent ones. If war becomes fashionable, democracies will follow that fashion with impunity.

Civil war is the worst kind of war and it is very imminent in many countries, large parts of Europe included, and that's a really bad thing, because when two states fought, you always knew who the foe was and often citizens weren't really involved (especially those outside the capital and far enough from borders). Of course due to the general lack of heavy artillery, bombing and other kinds of strike-heavy attacks, the number of casualties is smaller (then again it is nearly impossible to get accurate numbers during civil wars), but it often leaves the country more deprived of everything. If you look back at WWII it was, without a doubt, a terrible event in human history, but the nations were still able to recover from it fairly quickly, because the general society never stopped working (in the US women started to work in industries, effectively replacing the men fighting on the frontlines; Germany was in ruin, but the general society of productive age was still largely there and thanks to the financial support of the US (when it comes to West Germany), they were able to rebuild fairly quickly; same with Japan). Now compare it to a nation struck by civil war (for example the Balkans, who simply just continued WWII after the revolution - it's end was forced on them without a clear winner), those are usually left in ruin, because everyone tries to get as many of it's riches to themselves and more often than not they are (almost) completely deprived of people of productive age (especially men), hence having neither the resources nor capacity to effectively rebuild. That's why it doesn't take five or ten years to completely rebuild, but it takes easily twenty or more years, which again leaves the region vulnerable and unstable. And that's also why it sometimes would be better to leave the UN and other organisations out of internal conflicts, because again, if you look at their interventions for the past cca 10-12 years, they did more bad than good. To sum it up, rather than war becomming less or humanity becomming more peaceful, it seems the only thing happening is war becomming more business-like.

I'd like people to keep in mind that we will know very well when WWIII is over the horizon. If we look at the past two world wars:

Just before WW1 many of the great european empires were investing into larger armies and military technologies. Nationalism was on the rise as well and was sparking a lot of tension between nations. Everybody had their guns loaded and it was only a matter of time before someone pulled the trigger and let shit hit the fan. And that's exactly what happened.

Just before WW2, the news that there was a fascist reform in the German Government was a few years old (although fascism did not have as bad of a reputation as it did after the war). Tension was rising between Hitler and the allies as hitler had already made a violation of the Treaty of Versailles by remilitarizing the rhineland. Hitler had aslo annexed Austria and the allies had given him the Sudetenland (an area around the czech-german border, within Czechoslavokia, where many german speakers and people of german heritage live). Many germans were leaving the country while they still could. Even the USA started to conscript troops and prepare its industry for war, a country that hoped it would never have to enter the war prepared to defend itself if it did.

The next time there's a possibility of a war between major powers, I think we'll be able to feel it. If it will be anything like the past two world wars.

One clarification, we estimate the population of the Congo decreased by 10 million it's likely a good bit of that was lowered birthrate and disease.  Now much of that was caused by the depredations of the Congo Free State (the belgian king's name for his ruling there), but it's inaccurate to say that they were all killed or starved.

Leopold II (9 April 1835 – 17 December 1909) was the second King of the Belgians, also known for the founding and exploitation of the Congo Free State as a private venture. Born in Brussels as the second (but eldest surviving) son of Leopold I and Louise of Orléans, he succeeded his father to the throne on 17 December 1865, reigning for exactly 44 years until his death. This was the longest reign of any Belgian monarch.

Leopold was the founder and sole owner of the Congo Free State, a private project undertaken on his own behalf. He used explorer Henry Morton Stanley to help him lay claim to the Congo, an area now known as the Democratic Republic of the Congo. At the Berlin Conference of 1884–1885, the colonial nations of Europe authorized his claim by committing the Congo Free State to improving the lives of the native inhabitants. From the beginning, however, Leopold essentially ignored these conditions. He ran the Congo using the mercenary Force Publique for his personal enrichment. He used great sums of the money from this exploitation for public and private construction projects in Belgium during this period. He donated the private buildings to the state before his death, to preserve them for Belgium.

Leopold extracted a fortune from the Congo, initially by the collection of ivory, and after a rise in the price of rubber in the 1890s, by forced labour from the natives to harvest and process rubber. Under his regime millions of Congolese people died; modern estimates range from one to fifteen million, with the consensus figure climbing by around ten million. Human rights abuses under his regime contributed significantly to these deaths. Reports of deaths and abuse led to a major international scandal in the early 20th century, and Leopold was ultimately forced by the Belgian government to relinquish control of the colony to the civil administration in 1908.

Bad things are more likely to make the news partly because of how we process information and the second law of thermodynamics. Loosely, destruction is way easier than construction. If a building collapses, it happens in a moment and makes the news, but if one is built, it takes ages and doesn't. If a great artist dies, it makes the news - if a great artist is born, no one has any idea yet. If a crime or war doesn't happen or rates have been going down over time, it's generally not newsworthy, but a specific instance of crime or a battle will be. Even though the constructive events happen more, individually they take longer and mostly seem boring.

Part of the reason casualties are so low is because of the application of modern technology and highly developed military techniques. Why send 500 men to capture an area when you can simply clear it with a drone strike? It may cost more, monetarily speaking, but it's far more accurate than carpet bombing and it reduces casualties in the long run.

The soldiers of a modern army are also better trained and far more combat effective than their predecessors. New training techniques and better equipment means you need a smaller number of them and they're more likely to come home in one piece.
