3. Asia is the continent with the most hungry people - two thirds of the total. The percentage in southern Asia has fallen in recent years but in western Asia it has increased slightly.

4. Sub-Saharan Africa is the region with the highest prevalence (percentage of population) of hunger. One person in four there is undernourished.

5. Poor nutrition causes nearly half (45%) of deaths in children under five - 3.1 million children each year.

6. One out of six children -- roughly 100 million -- in developing countries is underweight.

7. One in four of the world's children are stunted. In developing countries the proportion can rise to one in three.

8. If women farmers had the same access to resources as men, the number of hungry in the world could be reduced by up to 150 million.

9. 66 million primary school-age children attend classes hungry across the developing world, with 23 million in Africa alone.

10. WFP calculates that US$3.2 billion is needed per year to reach all 66 million hungry school-age children.

The real reason war is slowing down is Star Trek. Whether they admit it or not, the Star Trek Universe is just so damned attractive to people. Look at the worldwide interest in warp drive. We already have personal communicators with access to a universal translator (there's an app for that!), and someone's figured out how to make transparent aluminum (He's not saying if he was visited by a crazy Scotsman in 1989). Science has successfully teleported one photon. Heisenberg Compensators (anti-gravity)are discussed in universities. The push for fusion (impulse drive); lasers as a power source- and then there's Mars.
Everybody knows that ST has at least two different timelines for History. Either we avoid The Big One, or we don't. In the first one, Efram Cochrane develops warp in a well-stocked lab & we ease into the future. In the second, he's a guy working in his Bladerunner garage.
But in both cases, it's the start. Of peace, real peace. And in our constant rewriting of our reality, we can almost see the steps that they took to reach it.
And y'know, it's just too tantalizing to ignore.

You should do a video on why things like this, and a nearly endless list of other complete mis-understandings of the world and life, are misunderstood. Specifically, the flaws in the human brain which evolved to survive (and only survive) in small tribes on the African savannah. The impossibility of hearing stories of violence 24/7 and being able to comprehend that those are drawn from such a titanically huge population that those exact stories, and their number, is proof of a lack of the violence which was far more abundant in the past, when it was simply harder to hear about. The 'Fear Constant' which human beings (and possibly other animals as well) appear to have, which requires them to maintain a certain level of fear about a certain number of things at all times - and how the removal of nearly all things actually WORTH fearing from our lives (by the infrastructure built by rational thinkers and intellectuals) leads inevitably to us wasting our time and energy wringing our hands in anxiety over absolute trifles of no significance (like violence or immorality in fiction! Holy hell has something so profoundly harmless ever been feared so much and for so long?).

Or, better yet, do a video on the biggest problem the human species as a whole faces: Once danger is removed from the day-to-day life of human beings, and it is possible for a person to be safe and comfortable regardless of whether they make decisions based upon critical thinking or upon intuition, large numbers of human beings will naturally cease exerting the effort required to engage in critical thinking, eventually resulting in them advocating destruction of exactly the infrastructure which keeps them safe. How is it possible to both remove danger from peoples lives, yet also give the majority of the population the visceral motivation to invest the effort in learning critical thinking and applying it in their life? If we do not figure out how to do this, then the 'civilized' world will fall apart as increasing numbers of people are unable to be convinced to continue the upkeep and expansion of the infrastructure necessary to keep their own lives safe.

Witness what has happened with vaccines in the US. Because the majority of people now raising children grew up healthy, without seeing their friends, siblings, and classmates dying and disfigured by terrible diseases, they are not willing to even permit their children to be protected from disease. They can not be convinced that the diseases are as bad as people say they are, or that vaccines are an effective protection which does more good than harm, because they have no visceral motivation. Instead of seeing the lady down the street cradling a dead child, they see her raising one with autism and she "just knows" vaccines caused it. And that's enough for them. Learning about vaccines and diseases and biology would be hard work.

And they'll be safe and protected no matter what. So why not just go with their gut? We can't just turn our backs and let their children die because their parents are morons. That would be to willingly abandon the exact safety and civilization we're trying to protect! We can't force them to be rational and to exert the energy necessary to doubt their intuition and trust reason instead - you can not force someone to think. As their numbers multiply, they will spread their ways of processing the world to others.

Eventually, they will tear down the infrastructure that keeps us all safe. And any time one of their bad choices hurts one of them, they will use the same means of dealing with those sorts of things that human beings used for thousands of years. They won't conclude their whole way of life is wrong and turn to reason. They'll blame gods or demons or superstitions or, most likely, they will blame whatever remains of the infrastructure they are fighting to dismantle. And because they are harmed, other people will listen to them. The people saying "we told you this would happen" or "you brought this on yourself" will be dismissed as arrogant or as blaming the victim. And it will spread.

This is the most dangerous issue facing the human species as a whole. In order to civilize, you must build infrastructure which removes danger and risk from peoples lives. Removing danger and risk from peoples lives also removes the visceral motivation to exert the effort necessary to overcome intuition and rely instead of reason. Relying on intuition leads inevitably to a belief that all of the effort spent maintaining infrastructure only comprehensible with reason is unnecessary. Public opposition to maintaining or expanding that infrastructure leads to its removal. Which leads right back to where we started. Can this be stopped?

There is no future for humanity under a democracy, especially a global one.

Populations are expected to increase to between 25 billion and 50 billion in the next 50 years. Already--with just 7 billion people--we are seeing fresh water shortages. Yes, we can turn salt water into fresh, but what does that mean for the oceans?

Without fresh water, food (as we know it today) cannot be grown.

And we won't mention oil products, especially gasoline which is increasingly being made by extreme measures...

You can't buy or trade for what isn't there (or is there, but in relatively small quantities) so you will be compelled to use force, in spite of world opinion. Indeed, since all of the developed world will be in as dire straits as you are, it would behoove somebody to commit to an all-out first strike to neutralize the effectiveness of the other countries. This wouldn't mean a "MAD"-style scenario, you just have to cut communications, electronics, GPS, and supply lines to all major cities within each country. The chaos within would be enough to put a stop to any counter-attack.

Although it is true that technically we are living in a relatively peaceful period of mankind's short 10,000 year history, it is a contrived "house of cards."

I'm not sure I buy this because it's missing a variable.  I don't think there is no war/is going to be no war; I think that war is changing.  With the development of new technology, it's becoming less manual (actually soldiers fighting other soldiers) and more digital (people sitting in front of a computer and sending drones to other countries).  And I don't even want to get started on how the creation of the internet has affected war.  Also, we can't exactly declare official war against another country if the enemy we're trying to defeat is not that country but something more like a rogue militant group that just happens to live in the country.  So, while according to the technical definition of war this video is accurate in saying that war might die out, I definitely don't think it's accurate to then assume that it means world peace is on the horizon.

I think another matter is that for most of the end of the 20th century, a sizeable population had witnessed the horrors of war. Many veterans from WWII were still alive. The Vietnam was was going on to give frightening memories to American, Vietnamese, and Chinese vets. India had just come out of a bloody partition with Pakistan, and three wars with same. Africa is constantly at war now with no shortage of people who know what war is like, and those are just a few examples.

Today though, many people who experienced war are starting to die off, and people who haven't experienced any suffering caused by war are taking up the population. Problems that were tolerable before are starting to rise as massive problems when they haven't really changed in scope or magnitude because people are more keen on violent solutions because they haven't been exposed to its consequences. All that is missing is a bogyman, and a "savior" that stands by an ideology, since most of the bloody wars in history are fought over economic ideology rather than resources (Religion counts as an ideology in this regard in a time when religion played a role in economics).

What is certain, though, is that the atom bomb has prevented the most war. Thanks to the atom bomb, all the major powers are too scared to invade each other. When a safe way to stop an atom bomb immediately before impact is developed, all cards are put back on the table, because we would have lost the element of MAD. It's just that war will look majorly different from what we imagine World War II to be fought like due to technology. Tactics will be a whole lot different when it is a war between a major and another major power, and it will most likely point to more killing of the civilians.

Its almost guaranteed we'll have a large war in the 21st century most large wars are caused by shortages of resources, changing ideologies, misunderstandings, or new ventures that may cause aggressive competition. Given our current path with the population increasing as much as it is and nearly 30 years of peace, its almost inevitable. Any number of shortages could cause a major war, food, water, fuel, and quite possibly land. Right now some area's are stressed but we can deal with it, and you are correct, it is currently cheaper to buy goods than take them by force, but what if the population was 10 billion? Water, food, and farmland for some of the big nations are becoming short. There's all this manpower just sitting around, hoping to ride out the storm and for governments to sort it out. Governments might decide at that point its cheaper to go to war, than it is to buy their way out of the issues, if they even could in the first place. there could even be global recession going on at the time when all the other issues break out.

What this means is that if things stay relatively the same as they are now, no we shouldn't have any more big wars, there's no motivation for such things to happen, and governments are usually uninterested in such things. However its rare that things stay the same for humanity and any number of things can change this fragile moment of peace. One only has to look to history to see this pattern before.

See after the Napoleonic wars, the nations of Europe created the Concert Of Europe to make sure such a large war never happened again, and for a long period of time it worked rather well, until a new large nation formed in the heart of Europe itself. Even then though, strong leaders with a commitment to never let the horrors of a European war happen again, it stayed together for a long time. But then newer leaders and new technologies entered the fray, and shortly after the great war was on. They too thought war would end.

Warfare is just a continuation of diplomacy with other means...
There will always be warfare because there will always be conflicts were no side is willing to agree on some level of compromise. In some examples one can even argue that a compromise isnt even possible. Like say ISIS values vs Western values and so on. There is no common ground within that conflict of interest so the natural outcome is a fight for dominance in order to dictate or see the losing side willing to concede aspects of their original demands or limitations.

For example take the difference between how a negotiated "cease fire" deal is differently seen within Civilian education and Military education. Within Civilian education a cease fire is seen as a good position towards lasting peace. However, within Military education a cease fire is seen as a good situation IF you can exploit it more than your opposition. Meaning the whole focus of a cease fire from a military point of view is to re-consolidate ones forces and be ready for new attacks etc and hopefully do it in such a way one out competes the opposition trying to do the the same. Leading to greater success on the battle field once the cease fire is over and fighting continues. Sort of like the break between Boxing rounds where the fighters are quickly patched up and given a few tips from their trainer rather than the end of fighting.

This is also why some cease fires just falls apart rather quickly... Because one side has reached the point that they have re-consolidated and re-organized their forces and are ready to fight, but want to do so before their enemies also get to that point.

Interesting that this video cites democracy as a cause for world peace. When people have a disagreement, the quickest way to settle it is by having one side relent, and war accomplished this by having one side beat the other into submission. Then democracy took the world by storm, where using debate to argue for one's own side became the norm. It started using rhetoric as opposed to manpower in order to come up with more sensible solutions. Yet, democracy still isn't enough... Good as it is to see that violence has been replaced with reason, there are still way too many logical fallacies, appeals to emotional reasoning, and underhanded politics at work for such a system to effectively solve problems. Think about how many BS excuses are given for the passing of inane laws. Heck, think about how easily voting can be chalked up to a simple popularity contest. Democracy has public approval, yes, and this keeps the people in line- but what happens in the long term when everything goes awry because the mob doesn't know what's good for them? War may be over, but instability? Poverty? Indecency?

We need something that'll let us properly enjoy our peaceful existences.

So, who has suggestions for an alternative system of government that'll help us to move on after we eliminate war?

This idea of less war is not a unique idea to the current international system. Over the past 1000 years, a general trend of liberalization has occurred reducing major conflict - with WWI and WWII being anomalies in a trend. The video fails to note perhaps the two most significant reasons why war will remain prevalent over the next century - the lack of sufficient oil supplies and water. What happens when oil begins to run out - a technological alternative? That is optimistic and the R&D funds for these technologies are nowhere near where they need to be right now. Water... a signifiant portion of the world already lacks sufficient access to fresh water and agricultural outputs to meet growing global populations are straining fresh water sources in countries even with significant reserves. How about disease? pharmaceutical antibiotics will arguably be ineffective in 50 years especially with the lack of new patent drugs being researched and antibiotic resistance reaching biologically unprecedented levels. The reasons this video identifies as causations for war are embedded within 20th century politics, not future politics. War is not ending, it is not less, it is simply different. It is fought differently and will be fought differently - and most importantly, it will be fought over for reasons that predominantly were not reasons for war over the past century.

While I enjoy the optimism of this video and while I don't dispute or disagree with any of the facts presented there of, the sad truth is that conflict is practically written in human nature. We war because we contain the mindset from birth that if we don't have something we want, we may never have it but I've certainly heard much stupider arguments for conflict. Not only that, but from my experience, it appears as though people of this generation are less interested in the world around them save a few funny pictures on the internet and they have no intent on figuring things out for themselves. misunderstanding or ignorance is one of the major factors of war.
We as humans seem to only take one of two choices when it comes to a topic or concept we don't understand. Either we try to understand, reach out to obtain knowledge about the topic at hand. Or, and I've seen this as the most prevalent through mainstream media (especially recently) and via many humans I know personally, we shun it. We shun what we don't understand and we lash out at it. We seem to despise what we don't understand and many if not most simply don't seem to know how to acquire the knowledge necessary to understand what we don't understand or we simply don't care enough to attempt to find out. We've reached a level of comfort where we all appear to create our own little bubbles, our private little safety zones. There is no adventure, there is no thrill of discovery, it could be argued both ways whether we've declined in regards to innovation and invention, and I personally fear that those bubble will pop very soon.

There was a time when getting your hands on a machine gun was very hard. Now it is quite easy. Today, it is hard to get your hands on a nuclear weapon. There will come a day when it will be much easier. I'll call it weapon inflation. Organizations that currently have the resources to have nuclear weapons are, predominantly, nation states. Their actions, at least in part, our congruent with the welfare and safety of their citizens. This makes them hesitant to use nuclear weapons, causing the "stability-instability paradox". Today, those who have nuclear weapons are rational. However, there will come a day when an organization similar to ISIS will be able to have their hands on a nuclear weapon. They will have no constituents to consider and thus they will be able to use nuclear weapons for their irrational goals. Someone irrational will someday get their hands on a nuclear weapon. Because of this, widespread destruction is a likely possibility.

The driving force (cause of it) for war is greed. Greed is not mentioned in this video. Why?

Greed, doing something to benefit one's self at the expense of others. Put another way, Fairness is treating others in a way we would need and want if we were they, its antithesis is greed. Organized greed is the stimulus for war. War erupts when a government becomes corrupt through the lack of an and effective justice system. War is simply the ignition point.

A world war happens when a greedy government grows in strength. The number of people being killed by violence by day is not a meaningful measurement of the magnitude of war, because the number of people is increasing or decreasing each day. To establish a more appropriate measure (normal in the mathematical sense) that number would have to be divided by of people on earth each day.

Motive or purpose needs to be assigned to wars. As the current middle east war has participants with the principle objective of obtaining control over oil production, it should be labeled Oil War. No pun intended here, it has the potential for an enormous eruption.

Personally I don't think humanity will ever be rid of war. Instead it will change in scale. Think about it. The first wars were fought by simple villages, then city-states, then nation-states, then multi-national coalitions. The next step after that are interplanetary wars (between Earth and space colonies in our solar system) and then interstellar wars (between the Solar System and other colonized star systems or perhaps even aliens). Eventually it may even get to the point where war will be fought between galactic civilizations and perhaps between the inhabitants of entire universes! But those last two examples may not happen for millions of years to come (if mankind is still alive, if woman can survive)

I'm not sure why fewer deaths resulting from violent conflict implies that the world is better now than in the past. It's not clear that dying in a violent conflict is much worse than the deaths caused by starvation, disease and climate chaos.

Most people watching this video in many ways benefit from a state of affairs in which many people die of these latter causes (though the benefit may be indirect). Our global institutions (which mostly act on behalf of the most affluent) often act so as to prevent change to this state of affairs.

You could either consider this a kind of violence, or at least something equally bad.

Only a few hundred thousand to three quarters of a million people died in each major war during the 1815-1914 period (with the exception of the Taiping Rebellion and Mexican Revolution). Even if you ignore the two world wars of the 1914-2015 period, you still get several major wars that claimed a million or millions of lives, like the Korean War, Chinese Civil War, Vietnam War, Iran-Iraq War, and the Congo War. And then you get the fact that yearly war related deaths have nearly tripled since 2010, only five years ago.

Like in 1914, this modern period of peace will only last as long as the post Cold War order will last.

Love the videos, but I think there's a major point lost here. Man's need for violence, some inexorable drive to dominate, isn't stopped because war was made harder by democracy and politics. What's stopping people is the understanding that war in this age, with our technology, and on the scale of the inter-connectivity and globalization we've already achieved, would mean the destruction of the Earth, and mutual death for all humankind. I'm not talking just about nuclear warfare that you touched on in the comment section. I'm talking about biochemical warfare such as weaponized diseases and toxins, dependency on technology and severing our access to said technology, even political strangulation can lead to the collapse of (in some sense) the fragile order of our governments.

As an example, simple actions can be complicated and contributory to mass discord due to our mass inter-connectivity. A white police man kills a black citizen, and thanks to media, facebook, and self-proclaimed authorities on criminal justice writing buzzfeed articles, general public revolt against the police force as a whole. Even if less than 1% of the force is involved in unethical behavior that's beamed into our houses by the internet. Same goes for Muslims, where xenophobic tendencies take root in average Americans because of extremists who likewise comprise of less than 1% of the Islamic people.

I think it's understood, then, by the people in power that not only is globalization cheaper than domination, but violence on the scale of even 50-60 years ago in any fashion would mean world-wide devastation, and that's in no one's best interests. Be that as it may, we should never let our guard down to the possibility of another full blown war. One conflict on the scale of WWII would mean the end of human life I believe. As you say, nuclear warfare treated as conventional warfare is such a scary prospect that we've fallen into a stability-instability paradox, but we should never forget the methods of madness spelling a slower, less dramatic, yet no less certain extinction. Disease, famine, inability to cope without our dependencies, all are just as scary.

These are all good points, but please look at the historical picture. Many scholars call this era in history as either the "Long Peace" or the "Pax Americana".

There is special significance to this last term. It started with the "Pax Romana", during the Roman Empire. There are many other terms like this, to denote other times in history where peace was at a temporal high. Pax Britannica between the Napoleonic wars and WWI, Pax Hispania during Spain's height in power. There are more.

There is a common thread between all these historically peaceful periods--the existence of a dominant power. John Meirsheimer made a good point in (http://mearsheimer.uchicago.edu/pdfs/A0055.pdf), that Europe has enjoyed a peaceful existence far longer than any in its history since the Roman Empire due to the existence of a unifying power. European governments resist the removal of US bases for this very reason.

I'm not trying to advocate a pro-American stance. I'm simply trying to say that there are far more reasons for this peace than "Democracy" and the modern condition. I'm saying that one should never let their guard down, and always defend peace, no matter the future conditions. As soon as conditions arise where it would be cheaper to take resources rather than buy them, war will raise its ugly head once again.

Not a bad presentation given the length of the video, and your point that the world has historically seen a reduction in overall levels of violence is well taken, but your evidence is flawed.
1. Democratic Peace
-There is a statistic in international relations which states that democracies, especially advanced democracies, do not go to war. Ever. There is a satirical statistic that claims the "McDonald Peace," that no two states in which the burger corporation functions has ever been to war.
-Furthermore, democracies are a new occurrence in the grand scheme of things and more data, and just more time, is needed to see if this theory is even true.
-It has also been shown that some of the most violent conflicts of the world in recent history are the result of states undergoing democratic transition. Are we replacing state v. state wars for rebellions and civil unrest?
2. Globalization
-Globalization of free trade can encourage peace. After all, why attack something you have an active stake in? Except, not all trade is equal. For example, if country A builds Gameboys and country B builds microchips, which state will lose out more should trade break down? In this scenario, country B won't really hesitate to war with country A if things come down to it because there are "critical resources" that drive the world: fuels, valuable minerals (talking about uranium and other industrial/weapons grade minerals not necessarily gold), and military sensitive technology. Globalization does not necessarily encourage peace as states are potentially willing to start a preventive war for the sake of hoarding these critical resources.

I left out Japan because Japan struck first, but that in itself was still an Act of war, and the US was in a state of war well after WW2 all the way to today due to the conflicts it was involved with. An act of war speaks for itself, invading or doing something that a nation  sees as aggressive and a danger to their existance, is usually met with that nation signing a declaration of war that lets everyone know that, they are at war. Just because casualties in wars aren't that of WW2 (20 million soviets dead), or WW1's estimated 17million dead, does not mean those who fought, died or those who were caught in crossfire who were killed, are a lesser thing than that of ww1 and ww2- they are just a smaller statistic of overall deaths.

One thing in support of "Wars going out of fasion":
In past times, war was seen mostly as a means of settling territorial disputes. WW I was probably the only exception from this rule...

There were many territorial disputes because territory usually came with valuable resources and most valuable of all - the population. This might sound wierd today, but in the past, when population was mostly rural, transfering a portion of population from one suvereignity to another was simple, because people did not care who held sovereignity over them as long as they were allowed to carry on doing their buisness.
There were some exceptions like collateral damage to population during the War, which forced some population to become refugees, or Religious problems, but mostly - an agressor was actually expecting most of conqured people to become his new subjects. And more population meant more taxes which was good.
Closer to present day, when institutes of citizenship and democrasy was introduced, this transition to different souveregnity was less ikely to hapen as people could express disagreement.
Later on, civil right were introduced. And people were demanding not only to consider their will, but also to uphold a level of wellbeing for them, creating social guarantees.

So eventually a population became not a source of taxes, but a source of headache for it's government.
his is basically the reason why we see countries split into autonomies, as more and more governments see it is better to leave people to handle their problems by themselves. Especially - you mentioned - global ecenomy enable having access to resources in another country without having to uphold the life levels on the teeritory (actually it is just the oposite - the less is the life level in a country - the easier it is for other countries to have access to it's resources, so sadly we see a lot of countries peing shoved into poverty by it's neigbors so that they can them exploit their resources for cheap).

It this world we are living in, a country MUST have a really good reason to even consider pulling more population (and thus more social expenses) to it's shoulders.

One of the most important reasons of why we don't have war nowadays are atomary bombs. It's the main reason, the Cold War mainly remained just that: cold. The moment you know that a war will likely cost you more than you can achieve by it (which comes pretty fast when atomary bombs are involved) you think twice about starting it. That's also the reason why quite some countries like Israel, North Korea or Iran want or wanted the atomary bomb so bad. Not to use them but due to their enormeous deterrence factor.

I think the key insight is that whatever your goal, war is no longer as good a strategy to achieve it.  This is especially true for advanced nations, who are in position to negotiate for their desired outcomes.  War now seems most useful only for trying to achieve an outcome that you desperately want but which no one would ever agree to allow.  With modern weapons, the likely cost of war between industrial nations is enormous (even if nukes not used) and always vastly exceeds the potential benefit.
For example, the US does not want want Russia to annex parts of Ukraine.  But I don't think we really want it bad enough to go to war over it.  Russia perhaps wants most of eastern europe.  But again, not so badly that they are willing to risk large scale war.  ISIL, on the other hand, really badly wants to set up a theocratic state.  No country is going to agree to that in exchange for anything that ISIL could possibly provide.  Hence they have gone to war to pursue this goal.

Nuclear weapons seems to be one of the main reasons the cold war didn't become warm.

In earlier grand wars, the people could be/and were tricked to think that their country had the best military, the best tactical advantage etc. Even rulers were "tricked" by their generals.
War was too complex for citizens to be able to acutally grasp the odds of an easy win, and assess the risk-reward function of supporting the war.

Nuclear weapons have simplified the whole deal. They have made the risk-reward calculations simpler and transparent.

My friends, it has often been said that I like war.
My friends, I like war.
No, friends, I LOVE WAR!

I love holocausts. I love blitzkriegs. I love defensive lines. I love sieges. Charges. I love mop-up operations and retreats.
Wars across prairies, in streets, in trenches, in grasslands, in frozen tundras, through deserts, on the sea, in the air. I love every act of war that can occur upon this earth!

I love blasting the enemy to smithereens with artillery salvos that thunder across the lines of battle.
My heart leaps with joy whenever a soldier is tossed high into the air and cut to pieces by well placed sniper rounds!
And there is nothing like a tank operator using a Tiger Acht-Acht to destroy enemy tanks.
And the feeling that comes when a soldier runs screaming from his blazing tank only to be mowed down by heavy machine gun fire is such an exquisite feeling.

Like when ranks of infantry brandish their bayonets rushing into the enemy line.
It moves me deep within my heart to watch a fresh recruit stabbing over and over into the bloated chest of a long-dead enemy.

The sight of deserters being strung up from a street lamp is an irresistible pleasure.
And there is nothing more arousing than the sounds made by prisoners of war dropping like flies, screaming in agony as they're mowed down by ear piercing Schmeissers!

When a band of pitiful resistance fighters makes their final stand with nothing but small arms, only to have their city smashed to atoms block by block by 4.8 ton bombshells, I'm in ecstasy.

I love it when my forces are ravaged by a Russian armored division. It's so sad to see towns and villages that were supposed to be defended at all costs, being laid to waste, their women and children being raped and killed.
I love to be squashed under the heel of the British and American war machines. The humiliation as my men crawl around like vermin, ducking the JAG bombers flying overhead.

here only as far as the Wars of America

War of 1812 (1812–1815) British interference with American trade, impressment of American seamen, and “war hawks” in Congress calling for western expansion into British territory led to war. At the war's conclusion, trade issues remained unresolved, but Britain gave up some of its territorial claims on the continent.

Mexican War (1846–1848) The U.S. annexation of Texas, and its stated desire to acquire California and other Mexican territory, precipitated this war. Mexico was forced to give up two-fifths of its territory. This land eventually became the states of California, Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico, and Utah.

Civil War (1861–1865) Economic and political rivalry between an agrarian South and an industrial North grew into a civil war fought over slavery and states' rights. Eleven states seceded from the Union to form the Confederate States of America. The Union victory led to the reunification of the country and ended slavery.

Indian Wars (colonial era to 1890) U.S. expansionism led to numerous military conflicts with the indigenous inhabitants of North America, forcing them to give up their land. The massacre at Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1890 is generally considered the last of these conflicts.

Spanish American War (1898) The U.S. supported Cuba's desire for independence from Spanish rule, and seized the opportunity to expand U.S. powers in other parts of the world. At the end of the brief conflict, Cuba gained its independence, and the U.S. gained several former Spanish territories: Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines.

World War I (1914–1918) Rivalries over power, territory, and wealth led to the “Great War.” In 1917, the U.S. joined the Allies (Britain, France, Russia, Italy, and Japan), who were at war with the Central Powers (Germany, Austria-Hungary, Bulgaria, and Turkey), after German submarines began sinking unarmed ships.

World War II (1939–1945) The Axis powers—Germany, Italy, and Japan—attempted to dominate the world. The Allies (U.S., Britain, France, USSR, and others) fought to stop them. The United States entered the war in 1941, after Japan’s attack on Pearl Harbor. Germany surrendered in 1945, and Japan surrendered later that same year, after the U.S. dropped the atomic bomb on the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Korean War (1950–1953) Communist North Korea, supported by China, invaded non-communist South Korea. UN forces, principally made up of U.S. troops, fought successfully to protect South Korea. The Korean War was the first armed conflict in the global struggle between democracy and communism, called the cold war.

Bay of Pigs (1961) The U.S. orchestrated the invasion, an unsuccessful attempt by Cuban exiles to overthrow Fidel Castro's communist regime in Cuba.

Vietnam War (1961–1973) In 1955, communist North Vietnam invaded non-communist South Vietnam in an attempt to unify the country and impose communist rule. The United States joined the war on the side of South Vietnam in 1961, but withdrew combat troops in 1973. In 1975 North Vietnam succeeded in taking control of South Vietnam.

Dominican Republic (1965) President Lyndon Johnson sent marines and troops to quash a leftist uprising in the Dominican Republic, fearing the island nation would follow in the footsteps of Cuba and turn communist.

Lebanon (1982–1984) U.S. troops formed part of a multinational peacekeeping force to help the fragile Lebanese government maintain power.

Grenada (1983) President Reagan invaded the Caribbean nation of Grenada to overthrow its socialist government, which had close ties with Cuba.

Panama (1989) President George H.W. Bush invaded Panama and overthrew Panamanian dictator and drug-smuggler Manuel Noriega.

Gulf War (1991) Iraq invaded Kuwait, and a U.S.-led multinational force came to Kuwait's aid and expelled Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein's forces.

Somalia (1993) A U.S.-led multinational force attempted to restore order to war-torn Somalia so that food could be delivered and distributed within the famine-stricken country.

Bosnia (1994–1995) During the Bosnian civil war, which began shortly after the country declared independence in 1992, the U.S. launched air strikes on Bosnia to prevent “ethnic cleansing,” primarily by Serbs against Bosnians. The U.S. became a part of NATO's peacekeeping force in the region.

Kosovo (1999) Yugoslavia's province of Kosovo erupted into violence in the spring of 1999. A U.S.-led NATO force intervened with air strikes after Slobodan Milosevic's Serbian forces uprooted the population and embarked on the ethnic cleansing of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian population.

Global War on Terror (2001– ) In the immediate aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, President George Bush launched the Global War on Terrorism—which has become the longest period of continuous war in U.S. history. The United Kingdom, several NATO countries, and other nations have participated to eliminate al-Qada and other militants groups.

Afghanistan (2001– ) The Taliban government harbored Osama bin Laden and the al-Qaeda terrorist group, responsible for the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States. After Afghanistan refused to turn over Bin Laden, the U.S. and UN coalition forces invaded. The Taliban government was ousted and many terrorist camps in Afghanistan were destroyed. U.S. and NATO troops remain in Afghanistan to support its fragile new government.

Iraq War (2003–2010) The U.S. and Great Britain invaded and toppled the government of dictator Saddam Hussein. Troops remain in Iraq to combat the insurgency that formed after Hussein's defeat.

It's not going to last. Peace only lasted this long because WWII was quite exhausting and nobody had the energy to fight afterwards. This is a broad statement and I don't have time to explain it.
Also, the unjustified optimism really bugs me. World peace has been tried before after WWI and it failed miserably mainly because countries like Japan still wanted to have empires, and they didn't, they couldn't, give a fuck about what the peace loving hippies were advocating. So if you think that UNO prevents wars, think of how USA invaded Iraq. UNO did not agree for an invasion, USA justified it with non-existing WMD, and, let's face it, even if Iraq had had WMD, why is that America's problem? I'm not saying the Iraq war was a bad thing. It was quite good, but it was unjustifiable in the technical world-peace-view sense. It brought democracy to those people, it killed Hussein, it brought American influence to the region, it did great things, but it was not a step towards world peace. And if you think about it, before WWII and after WWI, France's strategy was precisely world peace. They said it: "if Germany rebuilds its military we will not fight". How did that work? Did it achieve world peace? It didn't. Even if France's strategy were to fight or not, the war would had still happened and it would had still fucked France. So any step towards world peace is no step towards world peace.
Making war unprofitable is perhaps the main reason why we have fewer wars. And its also not seen anymore as something glorious. War is for loosers now.

Conflict is not over, the video never claimed it was. But here's what you patriotic young men are missing: you're the exception now. No one else wants war anymore. Human beings ARE changing. Never discount something as being "outdated"--wherever a new means of acquiring power is discovered (new weaponized technology) or an old means again becomes practical: it will be used. We like to look at time as being this continuous line, in some ways it could be viewed as such, but in experience we know that time manifests itself as the experiential present.

The experience of the present, of new possibilities, is a sort of "constant": people, animals, that lived thousands of years ago experienced their existences in the present.. as do ourselves, as do future generations. It feels as if it is always the present even though it is not. The important thing to understand is that since things only happen in the present, what we once had to deal with, what we once did, may all have to be dealt with and done again.

The perpetual present preserves potential possibilities. If it happened once, all that is required for it to happen again are the right conditions. It's all circular: each "day" we face similar opportunities, obstacles and choices..things progress in a cycle until we recognize that many problems are connected in a strange and fascinating way.
Ps. I talk about this kinda stuff but I admit I could learn to be less tense as a speaker (I suck at speaking haha), but I love this philosophical thinking. Science and philosophy are two parts that will allow us to conquer ourselves and the physical universe.

Thanks for the great video. Brilliant as always. There is one little, almost subliminal point that makes it a bit wrong.
Basically, Europe is the world's second most enlightened region - of course, after muslims, who invented pretty much all of maths and astronomy. Thus, it's not quite a pleasant sight to watch as these enlightened nations fall into this low-level, custom-made propaganda that would much better suit gentlemen from beyound the ocean. To put it short, Russia did not invade Ukraine. It's a kind of hilarious if you think about it, because Russia basically did not even lift her proverbial finger to intervene in what is going on there. If you study the most recent history, you would definitely find out that the Republic of Crimea declared independence and used its guerilla forces to secure its strategic objects. And then, as an independent state, it asked to be taken into Russian Federation (for those younger ones, Federation is a union of States, like USA). Russia consequently agreed. No military action was undertaken by Russia in this whole situation at all. What is happening in mainland Ukraine now is a pure civil war between two linguistically distinct parts of the population: the western ukrainians who mostly speak ukrainian and inhabit the less industrially developed region - and the eastern ukrainians, who mostly speak russian and inhabit (and, consequently, control) the rich industrial core of the state. Russia is not a fightier in this war. We can theoretize, of course, that this state is involved in some shadowy operations like selling weapons or providing information, but such accusations have no more ground than accusing USA of invading Ukraine. If we assume Russia is invading Ukraine, we have to assume on equal terms that any other country is invading Ukraine as well.

I have several "problems" with this video. It might be me going through this wrong, but here they are:

1. Violence is not just all out war. It's not even just physical, but that might be stretch...

2. It asserts colonialism is worse than the multinational corporations' actions by explaining what colonialism does and simply stating it's worse. It never even tries to get into the effects of economical dependency and abuse by corporations or even states. That's a very serious flaw imo!

3. Democracy is said to change everything, but the video never explains exactly how. And that 1900 year looks pretty much random to me! Also, wars between democracies and non-democracies don't always mean the "guilt" part of starting the conflict was the non-democratic part... That's just an assumption.

4. Buy resources? I'm pretty sure you can get stuff without buying (or buying cheaper) with means different than war, like espionage, economic and political pressures/threats, even covert ops (Just look at how the USA fucked up Latin America with all the CIA approved coups during the cold war, effectively making their economies dependent through non-democratic governments allied to 'murican interests).

5. People are more valuable alive than dead. That only makes sense if you think violence is only violence if it results in killing. What about all the slaves or almost-slaves living in underdeveloped countries so that democratic developed countries can have cheaper products? Imposed poverty and underdevelopment is violence! Vulture capitalism is violence!

6. The video ends stating that the sample is not big enough. Well... Doesn't that make the whole thing pointless? If we analyse the peace times in previous centuries, wouldn't we reach the same conclusion as the video reached?

P.S.: This is not intended to be a speech against democracy, the USA or capitalism in general. Although it is my opinion that most people regard those as awesome when in reality they also have many very very dark sides...

I have a couple of issues with the statements made in this video: 

1. Stating that democratization leads to a more peaceful world is a highly debatable topic, as it seems that it is simply not true when you factor in the fact that most democracies in the world are also Western nations that share a great deal of cultural similarities

2. The video completely ignored the role that nuclear weapons and the concept of nuclear deterrence have played in forcing this peace to occur, especially in forcing global superpowers to engage in other forms of warfare, such as economic, scientific (the "space race") or even proxy wars, all to avoid a nuclear exchange

3. You also fail to address the period from 1815 to 1914 known as the Hundred Years Peace where the European continent managed to hold itself together for the most part but, ended with the First World War. During this period there were many people who also believed that war was becoming increasingly irrelevant as a political tool 

And finally it is completely absurd to assume that the human race is moving beyond large scale armed conflict. For those of you who are quoting Fukuyama's "End of history" thesis it is correct in stating that the war for ideology may be over but, he completely ignores the fact that conflict existed long before nation states fought over ideology and war will continue to exist so long as humanity exists

3:36 A note on point #2: What they are talking about is capitalism and the free markets, though those terms are curiously never used.

In other words, capitalism is one of the greatest tools for world peace.

The whole idea of calling it "vulture" capitalism is itself a terrible misnomer.

Consider this: a poor girl grows up on a rice farm where her wages will be barely enough to feed herself.  She will work the fields 16 hours a day, seven days a week.

Along comes the fat, cigar smoking, greedy capitalist.  He offers to double her wages (to what would be still only a few cents a day) and she only has to work 12 hours a day in labor conditions that are much less strenuous than the rice fields.

The poor girl jumps at the opportunity, because this is a big step forward for her.

The rich greedy capitalist does indeed get away with super cheap labor, but those savings are passed to the consumer, as well as his own profits.

If we are to focus on the meager wages of the poor farmer girl, we might end up missing the bigger picture.  If we were to pay her much MUCH higher wages (say, something on par with the wages of the developed world) suddenly it is no longer economically feasible to offer the poor girl a new job to begin with.  Then it's back to the fields for her and others like her.

This is a very good and well-thought out video.  I've often observed that the people who constantly state that the world is growing more violent know very little about human history.  Even here in the United States, many people believe that crime is on the rise, when in fact violent crime per capita has been decreasing since the mid '90s and is currently at its lowest level since the 1950's.  The difference is that the 24/7 media stretches every notable crime out, analyzes every facet, in order to keep our eyeballs.  It reminds me of the trope of the "Wild West".  If you believe TV and movies it was one big gun battle.  But in fact, the frontier of the American West of the latter half of the 19th century was no more violent, and possibly less violent, then other places.  If crime was as common as is depicted, would we still remember the names of individual criminals like Jesse James or Billy the Kid?

Whenever you say democracy, you should really say plutocracy instead. Democracy would be nice, but meritocracy is even better. If there was democracy today, we could transition into meritocracy, but we apparently can't. I've sometimes wondered this myself, why in today's conflicts we don't have nearly as many people dying as we had in the past. Key to this is HOW we fight today. WWI - trench warfare, little to no bodily protection, and still pretty bad medical care = millions of deaths. WWII - blitzkrieg, massive waves upon waves of soldiers clashing, still bad medical care = again, millions of deaths. Korean and Vietnam, well I don't have to go into that but we started to get a little more bodily protection, not much, but fighting in the jungles and having a bit better field medicts = hundreds of thousands of deaths, still a lot but not that many considering how long the Vietnam war was.

The middle-east conflicts we are currently in and have been for a long time are much, much different. First, we use a lot more tactics, we don't have to send waves of expendable soldiers to overwhelm the enemy army, our soldiers are better protected with better bullet-proof vests and helmets, we have a lot better field medics (so many more soldiers now are coming home wounded than before. In early wars, you got wounded severely, you died. Now, limbs are being lost and still soldiers are saved). And, today its not like we're fighting army vs army. Fighting terrorists is a whole different ball game. You could save a group of people one day only to have them turn around the next day and shoot you in the back. We now have much better vehicles to travel around the ground with, protecting our soldiers from IED's and gunfire.

As long as there are major differences with people's views and some of those people want power by force, there will always be conflict. Unfortunately.

there are some interesting facts here, but this seems terribly naive.  as for the whole thing about "democracies don't fight each other"--perhaps democracies in the first world don't fight each other, but i could give quite a long list of conflicts caused or amplified by democracies since WW2 in the global south.  we're enthusiastically bombing syria/iraq right now, for instance, and it wasn't too long ago that western nations were all happily bombing libya.

i would also question how they're arriving at their casualty figures.  are they counting all the civilians killed by US drones in pakistan and yemen?  yes, full scale wars are much more grossly destructive, but given the number of people in the world living under neoliberal regimes, perhaps casualties need to be measured in a way other than simple deaths.  if economic colonialism is the new model for global domination, we can't simply use the old measurements for destruction and say things are getting so much better.

also, yes, we have an ICC, but that's just a means of dealing with crimes once they're committed, and then only by states that are small enough to be hauled before it--i.e., not the ones doing the most damage.  moreover it hasn't shown it has any ability to prevent conflicts from occurring.

this rosy picture also heavily depends on where you're living. it's fine to write off the few dozen conflicts going on right now if you live in britain or america, but if you live in syria or central african republic they are in no way just footnotes.  it's probably more honest to say that wars are killing fewer white people than they used to.

I like this angle better when it's put as relative comparable percentages: considering the world population amounts (vast growth), the amount of war casualties is down (smaller growth or even no growth of such amounts) - thus percentage wise, the segment of world populations engaged in warfare is over a certain period, diminishing.
But instead Kurtzgesagt attempts a brave but way too subjective number game, based on seemingly true definitions. It's a bit of taking a shit on actual statistics. Lulling people into the evocative ease of seemingly objective rationals.

But definitions that reveal themselves as blurry, when considered. Then their whole logic of numbers dies with it. Pity. An example; they suggest there's far less wars between countries and empires. But when is a country or empire, a country or empire? Those lines are drawn in hindsight. If people occupy a new territory long enough with long enough time of societal structure and identity, it gets recognized externally, eventually. That's how nationalisation works. And empires are almost always merely historical labels, based on looking back. Then there's the idea of civil war. Officially a war can be classified as a civil war, while in reality it's a myriad of geopolitical forces behind the scenes, who play out their national cards under the radar of explicit confirmation. Again, historically, such boundaries might be reconsidered dramatically in later hindsight.

I guess Kurtsgezagt tries something complex in a short simplistic pleasing manner. But perhaps that's just almost impossible for making 'real' arguments. Unless they do it a bit more postmodern, 2000's style, with a less authoritative and less self-unaware narrative. It's the inherent claim that provokes me into pointing out that it can't be taken on face value. Such narratives undo the attempts by nuanced social sciences that have tried to undue damages of that kind of narratives in the first place. We need contemporary analyses that take such reflexivity into account. The damages are real: assumptions via powerful short attention span media, spread quickly and deeply. Otherwise, we feed ourselves brain diarrhea. It's difficult. Vlogbrothers often pull it off due to their inherent vlogstyle of downplaying their authority. CGP Grey often picks saver topics that leave out contexts of such social structures and processes.

WWI started with local tensions over colonies and disputed borders in the 1890s, which degraded into regional tensions... then it went global. Same with WWII.

Democracy is still relatively new (not the concept, but it being widespread), and we already see cultural changes, mentality changes, and political changes that will challenge what democracy is.

You can barely call the US a democracy anymore. Its ruled by the rich, and the middle class/lower class is kept complacent via cultural distractions, such as reality shows, and consumerism, which promotes low attention span, and narcissism, leads to the rejection of responsibility, and all of that combined leads to ignorance and carelessness.

You can't have a functioning democracy, if the majority of the population is careless, scientifically illiterate, and ignorant about politics, because such a population is easily exploited by the ones holding power. You'll have a government that exploits its people, not one that represents their interests. People need to stop talking about getting sixpack abs, what celebrity X said on reality show Z, and instead start learning about psychology, argumentation, the importance of recognizing and accepting being wrong, and get at least basic college degrade in physics/chemistry/biology.

We need to wake up everyday and want to improve ourselves mentality, and have the psychological tools to do so. Only then can we have a future of peace, true democracy, and mutual respect and compassion. But hey that's just my opinion.

I usually love your videos but this one is just wrong, although this requires a much bigger discussion, I'll just mention two reasons.
-Democracy (as in the reason you mention for the proliferation of peace)  doesn't come hand in hand with today's ruling system, Capitalism. In fact, if what we can learn from the Chinese political system ("Capitalism with Asian values") tells us anything is that Capitalism works better without democracy. The trend today is towards Capitalism, not democracy, and the former thrives on conflict.
-The fact that you brush by what "peace" entails is the biggest problem. Peace IS the problem. The valuable lesson of common sense is to question how we can say we have "more" peace if it doesn't feel this way. The best example of this is to try to imagine telling someone who lost their entire family in a Narco war that today we live in a more peaceful era.
To equate the decrease in numbers of deaths to more peace is to be blind to the real problem.
